newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean prosecutors to delay arresting unionists.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean prosecutors to delay arresting unionists.

text.p: A senior South Korean prosecutor said on Monday the arrest of seven fugitive union leaders was being delayed because of prospects for dialogue over a controversial labour law.

"The principle of serving the arrest warrants still stands but execution of the warrants is being delayed in view of the prospect of resolving the current situation with dialogue," the senior state prosecutor said.

The prosecution official was speaking after a state television report that President Kim Young-sam would meet opposition leaders to discuss the crisis over the law, which allows companies to lay off workers and replace strikers.
Kim had previously ruled out such a meeting, insisting he would neither scrap the law nor revise it.
Seven members of the outlawed Korean Confederation of Trade Unions are sheltering from arrest at Seoul's Myongdong Cathedral.

On Saturday they backed down from a call for indefinate stoppages and said they would only hold strikes once a week on Wednesdays. Prosecutors had previously said the union bosses would be arrested if they did not halt industrial action immediately.
